newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-Holiday mood holds world commodities static. [CORRECTED 19:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Holiday mood holds world commodities static. [CORRECTED 19:00 GMT]

text.p: The price of commodities across the world hovered in tight ranges on Friday as markets in Britain and the United States prepared to shut up shop for the long weekend.
The price of coffee, base metals and precious metals gave a little in early trading but recovered later to finish around Thursday's closing levels.
One London-based gold dealer summed up the day .
"I think it's done for the day," the dealer said in the early afternoon. "With London and New York closed on Monday, people are going to head home early today."
The U.S. and U.K. markets will be closed on Monday for Memorial day and Spring holiday respectively.

Gold eased on the open to a low of $341.65 an ounce before a rally in silver dragged it back up 50 cents on the previous close to the $343 area. Dealers said it would spend the day in the $340-$345 range.
Silver raced ahead in the afternoon on fund and physical buying to a high of $4.79 an ounce before easing to hover around the $4.76 level, roughly five cents ahead of Thursday's close.
The platinum group metals were off the day's lows after suffering from selling overnight but sentiment was still bearish, traders said.
The price of coffee futures meandered around Thursday's closing figures.
The July New York traded arabica contract hit a high of 262.25 cents per pound compared to Thursday's close of 260.30 cents, only to drop a couple of cents later.
The London based July robusta contract hit a high of $2,110 a tonne but fell later to sit a few dollars below Thursday's close of $2,082.
With tight South American supply and low stocks in consumer countries the fundamental outlook for coffee prices was still bullish, dealers said.
The recent rally has been the longest for two decades and has pushed some contracts to 20-year highs.
Earlier this week prices received another boost when producer countries agreed to maintain cartel-style export quotas to lock in the gains.
Prices are likely to get more support as Brazil, the world's biggest producer, heads into the winter season with its potentially crop damaging frosts.
Coffee drinkers around the world are already feeling the pinch as roasters raise retail prices, and consumer groups have warned that consumption will suffer as people turn to cheaper substitutes.
Copper prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) hovered around the $2,510-$2,525 a tonne level on Friday with dealings largely reflecting book squaring ahead of the three-day weekend.
The red metal mounted several attempts to scale to Thursday's one-year peak of $2,530 in the afternoon but fell back to the range every time.
Despite technical signals showing copper is over extended, physical shortages lent support. LME warehouses have stood empty of copper since March 24.
Benchmark IPE North Sea Brent crude hovered around Thursday's close of $20.18 a barrel in quiet pre-holiday trading.
Wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade were a few cents lower again under pressure from favourable rainy growing conditions on the U.S. Great Plains.
